posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
That is, how are you meeting R409?  By joined segments, I mean that the segments along different sides of a robot are joined together, likely with metal angle.  The order of joined segment options is the same as the OK parts of Figure 8-7.  By different segments, I mean that the segment along one side of the robot is not attached to the adjacent side when removed from the robot.  Based on my experience, most teams do all four corners the same way, but if your corners are different, feel free to select all that apply and maybe do a post saying why they are different!

Secondary question - is this different from what you have done in recent years?  (and why).

joined segments, noodle bent around corner Joined segments, vertical noodle in corner Joined segments, mitered Joined segments, lapped Different Segments, mitered Different Segments, lapped Something else (please post to clarify) 0 voters

posts.name: Bryce Hanson
posts.cooked: I wonder if CD bias extends here too. Iâ€™d expect the majority of us are joined corner.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
I absolutely expect CD bias.  Only people on CD and similar social media would know that saggy bumpers can get you on a DNP list.

Even with that said, the most surprising thing to me so far is that nearly half of respondents are bending noodle around the corner.  As I related in the â€œAre We Doing Bumper Rightâ€ thread, I â€œsqueeze the charminâ€ all the way around both top and bottom to verify R408C and R409, and thus know how teams I inspect are filling corners.  I donâ€™t write it down, but I only recall pool noodle bent around the corner once in 7 local events Iâ€™ve RI â€™d (Bayou (3), Arkansas (2) , Magnolia(1) , and Talahassee(1)), and maybe three or four times combined at two CMPs.  [Out of about 24 teams I inspected bumpers; you get to inspect way more robots per event at CMP , because all the robots have been inspected already and there arenâ€™t nearly as many showstopper issues.]

posts.name: RoboGeek
posts.cooked:
I think part of why bending is still common is due to the aesthetic. Rounded bumpers, when done well, really look a lot more cleaner to their sharp corner counterparts.

A secondary factor might be â€œtop level teams do it, so letâ€™s do it tooâ€

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
Aaron_Li:

bending is still common

Well, thatâ€™s also opposite to my experience.  I went back through Game rules manuals, and the first time noodles bent around the corner was listed as acceptable in the Game Manual was in 2019.

posts.name: RoboGeek
posts.cooked: 195 bent theirs in 2018. Thatâ€™s when i first learned about this style

posts.name: RoboGeek
posts.cooked:
Letâ€™s be honest, 2018 isnâ€™t nearly as old enough to be such a trend.

With robot reveals as my primary source, my data is already biasedâ€¦ but I think itâ€™s probably safe to say bending noodles around corners became a West Coast thing. Maybe someone else invented it, but the further back you go, the less information there is archived, not to mention the quality of whatever video.

I primarily reviewed 118, 148, 254, and 1678.

148 in 2010 is probably the earliest sign of the bend, but they had a weird bumper that year.

254 definitely had a bend in 2011 . Itâ€™s highly probable that they had a full one-piece with bends in 2010, but itâ€™s hard to tell from match videos. Theyâ€™ve been bending ever sinceâ€¦ but as of this post, we donâ€™t know what they have for 2024.

118 didnâ€™t seem to pick up on bending until 2016 , which also happens to be an octagonal shape. This was probably also their first one piece bumper, considering previous years were multi segments. It doesnâ€™t seem like they bent in 2017 , but they did in 2018 .

For 1678, they had reversible in 2012, so itâ€™s not too clear if they bent; theyâ€™ve bent since 2013.

Other teams: 971â€™s first bend seems to be 2012 (bottom left corner).

Even 1323 in 2011 had bent bumpers

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
Previous to this year we were a bend the noodle around the corner team.  However in taking apart our last couple years worth of bumpers this fall we noticed that many of the noodles had failed (ripped) at the bends.  This year we are trying a vertical noodle in the corner.  I dunno, they donâ€™t look that different to me.

posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked:
It looks better it seems.  We tried bend around the corner this year and it does seem a little less cushioned there.

Unfortunately, we got caught by the bumper gap rule.  They were trying to remove a little bumper because originally the gapless version wouldnâ€™t go on because it needed a slight tilt that caused them to hit each other.  But removing material, now we have like a 1" gap instead of <0.5".  It is a hard mistake to fix with the tight tolerance.
posts.display_username: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)

posts.name: Nate Laverdure (he/him)
posts.cooked:
GeeTwo:

the first time noodles bent around the corner was listed as acceptable in the Game Manual was in 2019.

FIRST would prefer to keep it out of the manual! And they would, too, if it didnâ€™t immediately trigger qa questions

Official FIRST Robotics Competition Question and Answer System

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
I never said they werenâ€™t acceptable before, just when the Game Manual explicitly listed it as acceptable.

Iâ€™m confident there are those who will disagree with me, but I think the rules (especially the recurring rules) should be clear enough that most questions could be answered with â€œRule L### [perhaps with a sub rule or blue box reference] addresses this case.  If the rule is not clear, please restate the question to clarify the ambiguity or incompleteness.â€.  In particular, all teams should be on an equal footing in having the information available to understand the rules.

[Not saying they will understand the rules as well!]

posts.name: Robertson Robotics
posts.cooked:
I thought that bending the corner â€œAâ€ wasnâ€™t as protective because you were already compressing noodle before the collision? image 740Ã—381 63.2 KB Our team has traditionally gone with â€œDâ€ with our tank/westcoast drives but with us trying swerve for the first time, weâ€™re not sure whether to keep using â€œDâ€ or switch to â€œBâ€. Which one gives more protection to the robot?

image 740Ã—381 63.2 KB

image 740Ã—381 63.2 KB

posts.name: RoboGeek
posts.cooked:
It is indeed as you say. B and D are likely to be the most protective in the event of a corner-first collision.

I suspect most teams that do A do it for aesthetic reasons. You also shave off fractional surface area, but Iâ€™m not so sure teams are doing it for this reason.

posts.name: Phil Szymanowski
posts.cooked: You also make your robot diagonal slightly smaller by bending it around the corner rather than having a vertical noodle. Smaller diagonal means youâ€™re a harder target to defend.

posts.name: RoboGeek
posts.cooked:
I did say that, but I personally felt the difference would be negligible that it wouldnâ€™t make a difference if your bumpers were A over D.

For swerve teams, itâ€™d definitely be easier to roll off of, than a full corner, but teams have mostly adapted to avoidance as you keep your momentum.

posts.name: Robertson Robotics
posts.cooked: Has anyone seen a notable difference between the lapped corner and the vertical post? In my mind it seems like the vertical post would give more protection, but on the other hand, the additional cuts/joints in the corner might make it weaker.

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked: At this point Iâ€™m filling them with cement so that we can make it to our second match.
